direction.raw_text: The blade of a knife. Pulled from its sheath, intricate tribal etchings on the blade catching the light. The blade being pulled across a sharpening stone. Swoosh- swoosh-swoosh. Rhythmic. A well-practiced hand. A muscular, tattooed arm. The blade held up. Razor sharp. The glow of a TV in the darkened room is the only illumination. We see images on the TV:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: slums barricades poverty starvation demonstrations repression refugee camps barbed wire prisons riot police tear gas violence... Then the images settle to now, BREAKING NEWS:
direction.name: direction

result.heading: "DOGS MUST EAT," "MEAT WAS MADE FOR MOUTHS

direction.raw_text: . Images of a protest march. A crowd filling the streets. Soldiers moving into position. We see placards: "DOGS MUST EAT," "MEAT WAS MADE FOR MOUTHS." The man sharpening the knife watches the images. His eyes are cold. Almost disinterested. Then he stops. Frozen in mid-stroke. Something on the TV suddenly rivets him. His eyes no longer cold. The TV shows one of the soldiers, a high-ranking officer. Imperious. Giving orders. We will come to know this is a man as Caius Martius -- Coriolanus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the man sharpening the knife, gazes at the image on the screen. He leans forward. Emerging from the darkness. We see his face. He is a handsome and imposing figure, magnetic in his personality. Charismatic, yes, but also neurotic and edgy. Uncomfortable in his own skin. Some demons there. He watches the face of Caius Martius on the TV screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Then he puts the point of his knife against the screen. Against Caius Martius' heart. Holds it there Presses the point against the screen Muscles knotting in his forearm As if he could thrust the knife through the screen and into the heart of Caius Martius... His nemesis His dark angel. Sharp cut to--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We move with an intense woman down the street. She is nervous. Checks she is not being followed. She is TAMORA, an extreme figure on the political landscape. To the Roman elite she is a dangerous anarchist -- to her supporters she is an ardent patriot and democrat. As she moves, we take in Rome. It might be Mexico City. Or Chechnia. Or El Salvador. Or Detroit. Or Baghdad. Or London. This Rome is a modern place. It is our world right now: immediately recognizable to us. Elements of classical architecture loom over decay. Monolithic modernism and brave public monuments are lost in a sea of brazen advertising billboards, neon shopping plazas and drab super-highways. Splendor and squalor sit side-by-side. It is a volatile, dangerous world. William Shakespeare's Rome. She comes to a graffiti-covered apartment building. Looks around. Enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A secret political meeting in a police state. Tension. Cigarette smoke hangs in the air. Men and women gathered, hushed and urgent tones. A cell meeting of the political opposition, the resistance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: shows the food marches elsewhere in the city. The gathering storm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is a leading proletariat organizer:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Before we proceed any further, hear me speak -- You are all resolved rather to die than to famish? The others agree. They are not wild-eyed radicals. They are normal people, from all walks of life. You and me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: First, you know Caius Martius is chief enemy to the people. A voice from the back of the room:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let us kill him. The others turn. Tamora, just entering, pulls off her coat, joins the others:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And we'll have corn at our own price. Is it a verdict? Some are unsure. She is too extreme for some.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are accounted poor citizens, the patricians good The leanness that afflicts us, the object of our misery, our sufferance, is a gain to them. Let us revenge this with our sticks ere we become rakes! I speak this in hunger for bread, not in thirst for revenge. A woman, a YOUNG MOTHER, protests:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Against him first.

Then the TV image switches to a BREAKING NEWS update: From the Roman Senate. An august press room. A Senator is moving to a podium to make a statement. He is Senator MENENIUS is a seasoned and wily politician. Silver hair, perfectly tailored suit. He is known as a folksy "man of the people." It is a role he plays to perfection.

direction.raw_text: He's one honest enough; would all the rest were so.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STREETS - DAY Tamora, Cassius and the others are now in the midst of the protest march. The crowd has become a mob, with a life and will of its own. The crowd surges forward-- They round a corner and suddenly stop-- For a formidable sight awaits them-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Rows of black uniforms. Full riot gear with plexiglass shields and dangerous truncheons.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . A few soldiers on horses as well. The crowd starts and shifts nervously, unsure how to proceed. Should they launch themselves against this monolithic military force? A long, tense beat. Then... One of the horsemen trots forward... He rides a beautiful white horse... It is CAIUS MARTIUS. (Soon to be given the honorary title Coriolanus.) He is intense and patrician. Uncompromising. A man of steel. A soldier. He wears a crisp, military uniform. From his position on the horse, Martius looks over the rioters... His gaze is ice... A long beat... Then he dismounts... He slowly walks to the unruly mob... With no hesitation, unarmed... He stops before them... And speaks with absolute disdain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the matter, you dissentious rogues, That, rubbing the poor itch of your opinion, Make yourselves scabs?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have ever your good word.

direction.raw_text: Beneath abhorring. The crowd is hushed. Taking in his every word.

direction.raw_text: . We note a TV news crew has moved into position and is filming eagerly. Some in the crowd film with cell phone cameras. Streaming video. We intercut some of these perspectives.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What would you have, you curs? He that trusts to you, Where he should find you lions, finds you

direction.raw_text: Who deserves greatness Deserves your hate... Hang ye! Trust ye? With every minute you do change your mind, And call him noble that was now your hate, Him vile that was your garland. He continues along the crowd, his cold eyes taking in face

direction.raw_text: Go GET YOU HOME, YOU FRAGMENTS! A tense beat. The riot police shift nervously. The crowd is unsure. The TV news crew films everything.

direction.raw_text: . Cassius looks around. He sees the police ready with tear gas. He sees old men, women and children in his crowd. He doesn't want this to explode. He exchanges a few whispers works with Tamora. Word is passed and the crowd begins to disperse. Some run off in a panic. Others walk away. The danger has passed. Senator Menenius, who has been watching from nearby, gestures for Martius to join him. He is an old family friend of Martius' as well as his mentor and chief political advisor. Menenius is relieved bloodshed has been avoided.
direction.name: direction

He runs his knife blade back and forth. Turns it in the light; the reflection of Martius' face distorting as he rotates the blade.

direction.raw_text: The news is the Volsces are in arms. An aide presses a remote. Grainy video images play on a monitor: Volscian soldiers, jeeps, tanks. One section shows a quick image of the rebel leader, a striking man called Tullus Aufidius, riding past in a jeep.

direction.raw_text: The same face. Aufidius, who is the leader of the rebel Volscian forces, stands deep in thought. The Volsces are an insurgent force challenging the monolithic might of Rome: rebels that suggest to us Latin American revolutionaries or Hamas fighters or Chechnian separatists. They are a dangerous guerilla force. We are in the Volsce war room in an old apartment building. A basement. No windows. Secure.
direction.name: direction

Aufidius' eyes spark at the image of Martius. He picks up the magazine and carefully tears off the cover picture of Martius, looking at the picture deeply. He continues with a strange and grim fire:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beautiful butterfly. Catching the light perfectly, almost iridescent. It floats before a palatial mansion in the suburbs of the great city. Manicured lawns. Formal gardens. Classical architectural lines. This fine home of aristocratic privilege seems a world away from the urban blight of Rome. In the immaculate front gardens YOUNG MARTIUS, Martius' son, is playing. The boy is about ten. There is something grim and lonely about him, without charm. Young Martius chases after the butterfly, trying to catch it. He fails. The butterfly flits away. Young Martius leaps after it. Again he misses. Finally the frustrated boy manages to catch the butterfly. In his rage he tears it to pieces, brutally shredding it. We realize he is being observed...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . VIRGILIA, Martius' wife, stands at the window. Disturbed by the sight of her son ripping apart the butterfly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . She sees Young Martius stop and look at the tiny bit of blood on his fingers. Young Martius is unmoved. He glances up. Locks eyes with his mother. She turns away. Virgilia was well-chosen for her role as wife to one of Rome's most aristocratic men. She is beautiful and graceful but -- like Diana thrown into lion's den of the Windsor family -- woefully out of her depth. We feel an inner fragility to her. The room is spacious and elegantly appointed. A lovely Roman statue in one corner. This is a place of wealth, order and control. A fine flat-screen TV flickers with images of war. We see helicopters zooming over desert landscape Imbedded war correspondents Tanks Combat Romans . Volscians.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Martius' mother, stands and watches the TV. She is an imposing woman, handsome and tall, impeccably dressed. Adamantine in her strength. Virgilia moves from the window. Sits on a sofa. She watches the TV news footage of the war, upset by the images. A frozen silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I pray you, daughter, sing, or express yourself in a more comfortable sort. If my son were my husband, I should more freely rejoice in that absence wherein he won honor than in the embracements of his bed where he would show most love. She moves across the room to fetch a cigarette. She moves, always, with stately grace. She walks past a series of photographs. They tell the story of Martius' life: the happy baby; the stern dead father; the rigid young military cadet; the formal wedding; the restrained and unsmiling adult. In the photos we sense a transformation: innocent boy to experienced, severe looking soldier. Volumnia is present in most of the pictures.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When yet he was but tender-bodied and the only son of my womb, I, considering how honor would become such a person, was pleased to let him seek danger where he was like to find fame. She lights her cigarette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To a cruel war I sent him, from whence he returned, his brows bound with oak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But had he died in the business, madam, how then?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then his good report should have been my son. (she rivets Virgilia) Had I a dozen sons I had rather have eleven die nobly for their country than one voluptuously surfeit out of action.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: enters. She speaks to Volumnia (the true mistress of the house) not to Virgilia.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Madam, Senator Menenius is come to visit you.

direction.raw_text: Let her alone. As she is now, she will but disease our better mirth. She takes Menenius arm and pulls him out, eager for more news of her son. Virgilia sits for a beat. Then she presses a button on the remote control. The TV goes on again. More news reports of the war. We see images of the Volscian town of Corioles. A "BREAKING NEWS" scroll runs across the bottom of the screen The Battle for Corioles Virgilia watches the war footage, her eyes haunted. Hard cut to--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! BLAM! BLAM! A series of explosions jolt us. Corioles is a small urban center. Smoke billows up from areas of the city. The steady crack and rattle of gunfire. The occasional thud of explosions. We see urban street-to-street fighting. The images are startling in their familiarity: this could be Basra or Belfast. The battle is photographed in a gritty exposure. Color is drained out -- blood is a darker red like oil. Soldiers are dark forms moving through shadows and smoke. Martius and Titus, leading a platoon of around twenty Roman
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: run into view and take cover. Bullets zip and snap around them. The Roman soldiers wear modern battle fatigues and body armor, tricked out with all the latest tech gear. The Volscians, being a poor guerilla force, wear thrown together uniforms that look almost tribal. Martius calls over the incessant din of battle to Titus and
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They fear us not, but issue forth their city. Sniper bullets slam into a wall near him. He coughs away the smoke and debris. This only makes him more angry:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They do disdain us much beyond our thoughts, Which makes me sweat with wrath! He that retires, I'll take him for a Volsce, And he shall feel mine edge! Martius leaps up and races on. The others follow in military order. The Roman soldiers move along the street -- it is chaotic -- explosions, smoke and sniper fire -- they duck into doorways and behind abandoned cars -- returning fire as best they can-- Martius leads -- firing stead bursts from his machine gun-- It is slow and bloody going-- Finally the Romans turn a corner and are stopped by a roadblock: a burning bus that fills the entire street-- The Volsces use this roadblock to ambush the Roman soldiers-- We see glimpses of Volscian soldiers darting for position -- firing from rooftops and from inside shops--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BLASTED HOTEL ROOM - DAY Aufidius runs into a blasted hotel room. Some of his soldiers with him. He goes to the window. Scans the street below. Sees Martius and the others trapped at the bus. He gestures to an aide for
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CORIOLES-STREET - DAY In the face of the crossfire, the Roman soldiers start
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Martius refuses to yield -- pushing and shoving his men toward the burning bus -- screaming in fury over the noise:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You souls of geese, That bear the shapes of men! PLUTO AND HELL! All hurt behind! Backs red, and faces
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With flight and agued fear! Mend and charge home, Or, by the fires of heaven, I'll leave
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! An EXPLOSION -- dirt and brick shards slash across Martius' face -- blood-- This only pushes his fury to white rage--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look to it. Come on!

result.heading: THE FOE AND MAKE MY WARS ON YOU

direction.raw_text: ! He leaves his soldiers behind-- Moves alone to the burning bus and fights his way through the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Martius is in his own world now. He doesn't even realize he is alone. He has become a sort of killing machine. A shark moving through the ocean. Ruthless and efficient. We become the warrior. From Martius' POV: We move through disorienting curtains of smoke... Continue down the street... Firing a heavy machine gun... Volscian soldiers contort and die, torn to pieces by the bullets... The heavy machine gun is empty, we drop it and use a sidearm, firing strategic shots... Volscian soldiers dart up -- fire -- and die... We keep moving steadily forward... Shadowy shapes moving nearby, we fire. Killing civilians. The fortunes of war...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Strange surreal images. We smash into a house. An OLD MAN crouches, terrified, in a corner. He reaches forward. He is offering us water. An act of kindness amid the carnage... We move on... Panicked civilians, scattering in terror... Volscian soldiers rush us, attacking, we slam them aside... We duck down, roll under a car, emerge and fire... More Volscians die... We continue forward... Then the pistol is empty, we drop it and pull a machete-like knife... Still moving relentlessly forward... Slashing and killing... Hand-to-hand now... Carnage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aufidius and his aides are racing down an alley, trying to get to Martius-- Roman fire stops them-- They return fire as they divert down another alley, trying for a better strategic position, running flat out--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Titus and the soldiers are still pinned down at the burning bus. Two soldiers race back to Titus to report, they dive for cover.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is become of Martius?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Slain, sir, doubtless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is himself alone, To answer all the city.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thou art lost, Martius... Titus has no time to mourn. He looks over the hopeless situation. Scanning the rooftops, windows and shops. Then he stops He sees something Past the burning bus Through the smoke and flames... He glimpses a ghostly figure...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's yonder, That does appear as he were flayed? 0 gods! He has the stamp of Martius. It is indeed Martius. A shocking sight. Drenched head-to-toe in blood. His face splattered with gore. His eyes wild. Lost in something like rapture.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come I too late?! Come I too late?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ay, if you come not in the blood of others, But mantled in your own. Martius laughs wildly and embraces Titus, who comes away splattered with blood:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Martius scans the location. Sees the attack is coming from an old Hilton hotel. Now pockmarked with bullets and artillery shells. Most of the windows shattered. This is the Volscian stronghold. The last stand. He sees flashes of Volscian soldiers moving on the roof and balconies, and snipers firing from windows. There is an open plaza, littered with bodies and debris, in front of the hotel. Martius stops scanning with his binoculars-- Sees Aufidius moving in the hotel, directing the battle--

direction.raw_text: Wherein you see me smeared; if any fear Lesser his person than an ill report; If any think brave death outweighs bad life, And that his country's dearer than

direction.raw_text: Let him alone, or so many so minded, Wave thus, to express his disposition,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! The soldiers are pumped up -- like Marines straining for
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! MAKE YOU A SWORD OF ME!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Zigzagging across the plaza toward the hotel-- Titus and the others provide covering fire--
direction.name: direction

result.heading: MAKE YOU A SWORD OF ME

direction.raw_text: Martius zigzags with his men across the dangerously exposed
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They return fire at the hotel as best they can, but the barrage from the Volscians is murderous-- Roman soldiers contort and fall, blood spraying-- Bullets snap and ricochet everywhere around them-- But still they keep up a steady pace, reloading and firing as
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then Martius is hit--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But still he keeps on-- The front of the hotel is closer now-- Martius and his soldiers race to the hotel and crash into the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CORIOLES-HOTEL-LOBBY - DAY Martius and his soldiers battle the Volscian defenders in the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is the weird and incongruous nature of modern urban warfare: soldiers fighting to the death among hotel couches and tatty corporate artwork-- It is brutal-- Martius and his soldiers cut a bloody swath across the hotel
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another HUGE EXPLOSION rocks the hotel -- like a seismic blast -- an ugly 1970's chandelier falls--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Martius and his men move into a stairwell--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Martius and his men race up the stairway- Volscians are firing down at them-- Bullets ricochet crazily in the confined stairway, refracting from concrete walls and twisting metal railing, sending up sparks and clouds of dust-- Then Martius slows to a stop. Looks up. Aufidius is on the stairway above. Glaring down at him. A long beat as they lock eyes. Both panting for breath in the heat of the combat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll fight with none but thee, for I do hate thee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We hate alike. Then Martius does something astounding. He holds out his arms to his sides and drops his weapons. They clatter down. Aufidius does the same. The Roman and Volscian soldiers watch. None daring to interfere. Martius and Aufidius continue to glare at each other -- dropping weapons -- disarming -- Martius climbing up the stairs, Aufidius coming down -- moving closer and closer-- At an instant- They slam together- Fighting without weapons-- Grappling brutally. Tearing at each other. Twining together. Fingers grasping. Teeth snapping. Hands pulling. It is a bloody, terrible, graceless struggle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . They crash and slam awkwardly in the claustrophobic stairwell. Smashing into the walls. Falling from level to
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another EXPLOSION rocks the hotel-- Part of the roof COLLAPSES-- Concrete SLAMS down-- A cloud of smoke, dust and debris obscures everything- Martius is tossed violently to the ground in the action-- Aufidius is pulled away by several of his men. They drag him to safety. Roman soldiers fire after them. The sound is deafening in the confined garage. But Aufidius and his comrades disappear into a cloud of dust. Gone. Martius glares after him. Wipes blood from his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The hotel lobby has been turned into a hastily assembled emergency triage station. The moaning and screaming of the injured are constant. Roman medics attend to the wounded: administering IVs; arranging evacuations; performing battlefield surgery. Martius sits, dried blood covering his face, looking over his injured and dying soldiers as a medic stitches up a wound in his arm. Titus is with him. General Cominius enters with several attending officers, going to congratulate Martius.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I should tell thee over this thy day's work, Thou would not believe thy deeds. Martius is barely listening. His attention is on a YOUNG SOLDIER across the room. The Young Soldier is injured, pale and thirsty. Dying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I'll report it Where Senators shall mingle tears with (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where great patricians shall attend and shrug, In the end admire and say: "We thank the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Our Rome hath such a soldier."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pray now, no more. My mother, When she does praise me, grieves me. I have done as you have done - that's what I can; Induced as you have been - that's for my country. Martius continues to look at the poor dying soldier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rome must know The value of her own. It were a
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Worse than a theft, To hide your doings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have some wounds upon me, and they
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To hear themselves remembered. The surgeon finishes stitching Martius' arm. Starts to clean another wound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Should they not, Well might they fester against
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Too modest are you. Impatient, Martius rises, painfully and slowly. He takes his canteen and crosses to the Young Soldier. Gives his canteen to the boy. The Young Soldier drinks. His deep, sad eyes gaze up at Martius. Martius watches as... The Young Soldier dies. The light goes from his eyes. His head hangs awkwardly. His boyish face is leaden. Martius suddenly finds himself exhausted. Morally and physically spent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will go wash; And when my face is fair, you shall
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whether I blush or no Howbeit, thank you. Martius stares at the dead soldier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aufidius and some of his Volscian soldiers, bloody and filthy, are on foot. They are moving through the outskirts of Corioles, leaving the city. Exhausted after the long and failed battle. Fires burn from blasted shops and homes. The Romans have clearly laid waste to this part of the city. There is a minivan stopped ahead of them. Bullets holes everywhere. Bodies inside. They walk to it. Aufidius looks in. A dead family. Father, mother, kids in the back. Bloody toys on the floor of the minivan. Roman atrocities. Aufidius gazes at the bodies. His face hardens. He whispers to himself:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Five times, Martius, I have fought with thee; so often hast thou beat me, And would do so, I think, should we
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As often as we eat. He becomes aware some of his men are looking at him, disturbed at his fervor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought to crush him in an equal force, True sword to sword, I'll stab him some way, Or wrath -- or craft -- may get him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's the devil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bolder, though not so subtle. A beat. Aufidius continues with prayer-like intensity:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My valor, poisoned with him, Shall fly out of itself ... Nor sleep, nor sanctuary, being naked, Sick, the prayers of priests, Nor times of sacrifice, Shall lift up their rotten privilege And custom, Against my hate to Martius. In the shattered glass of the minivan window, Aufidius suddenly sees himself. He studies his own face, nurturing his dark thoughts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where I find him, were it At home, upon my brother's guard, even there, Will I wash my fierce hand in his heart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Back in Rome, we are at a comfortable restaurant/bar near the Senate where politicians gather to eat, drink, gossip and conspire. The business of state is conducted over steak and martinis. Comfortable red leather booths. Wooden panelling. Two Tribunes -- Senators chosen to speak for the people -- are having lunch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is a large man in a rumpled grey suit; a sweating bear with a taste for bare-knuckle politics. SICINIUS is smaller and vulpine; crafty and cold. Both are ambitious politicos used to manipulating the people and the press for their personal ends. With them sits Cassius, the political agitator we met before. The TV over the bar shows images of Martius' victory: parading Roman troops; Volscian prisoners; flags; adoring crowds; triumphant slogans; "Mission Accomplished."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Was ever man so proud as is this Martius?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He has no equal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When we were chosen Tribunes for the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marked you his lip and eyes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nay, but his taunts. They see Senator Menenius approaching. Sicinius nods to Cassius, who quickly goes. Menenius stops by on his way out. He is jolly, knowing the victory will assure his protege's political future:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The augurer tells me we shall have news tonight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good or bad?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not according to the prayer of the people, for they love not Martius.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nature teaches beasts to know their friends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You blame Martius for being proud?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We do it not alone, sir. Subtly, the polite chit-chat is turning more serious and pointed; Menenius growing sharper. The gloves are coming off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know you can do very little alone You talk of pride: 0 that you could turn your eyes toward the napes of your necks, and make but an interior survey of your good selves! 0 that you could!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What then, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why, then you should discover a brace of unmeriting, proud, violent, testy magistrates, alias fools, as any in Rome. The saturnine Sicinius' response seems almost a threat:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Menenius, you are known well enough too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am known to be a humorous patrician, and one that loves a cup of hot wine with not a drop of allaying water in it; one that converses more with the buttock of the night than with the forehead of the morning. What I think I utter, and spend my malice in my breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come, sir, come, we know you well enough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know neither me, yourselves nor anything You are ambitious. A tense beat. They are formidable adversaries.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good-e'en to your worships. More of your conversation would infect my brain, being the herdsmen of the beastly plebeians I will be bold to take my leave of you. He goes. The Tribunes watch him cut through the lunch crowd and exit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Roman Senate is constructed with classical symmetry and clean, square lines. Probably the most striking and beautiful building in Rome.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Volumnia, Virgilia and Menenius are hurrying down a corridor, excited. All are well-dressed, for an important public event.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Honorable Menenius, my boy Martius approaches! For the love of Juno, let's go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is he not wounded? He was wont to come home wounded.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: no, no, no...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 0, he is wounded! I thank the gods for it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So do I too -- if it be not too much. Brings a victory in his pocket, the wounds become him. Has he disciplined Aufidius soundly?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Titus Lartius says they fought together, but Aufidius got off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In truth, there's wondrous things spoke of him. Gods grant them true.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (an exhalation of scorn) True?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be sworn they are true. Where is he wounded? Volumnia and Menenius now gleefully add up her son's wounds like accountants -- or campaign managers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the shoulder and in the left arm. There will be large scars to show the people, when he shall stand for his place He received in the repulse of Tarquin seven hurts in the body.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One in the neck, and two in the thigh - there's nine that I know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He had, before this last expedition, twenty-five wounds upon him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now it's twenty-seven. Every gash was an enemy's grave. We focus on Volumnia's face as she thinks about her son.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He carries noise, and behind him he leaves tears. Death, that dark spirit, in his nervy arm
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Which, being advanced, declines, and then men die. They hurry to the stop of a grand staircase, where there are people waiting...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They join Cominius and other dignitaries at the top of a majestic stairway. An honor guard of Roman soldiers in dress uniforms are waiting. Roman flags flutter. All very ceremonial. Martius enters below. The honor guard snaps to attention. Martius -- hereafter called Coriolanus -- slowly begins to cross to the steps. We see that walking is very difficult for him. His wounds are severe and every movement is agony. He has paid a steep price for his victory. Photographers flash photos and a TV crew film the ceremony. Coriolanus finally reaches the steps leading up. He takes a breath and slowly begins to climb the stairs, each step a challenge. Volumnia looks down on him. Unmoved by his pain. Virgilia is distraught. As Coriolanus slowly hauls himself up the last few steps, General Cominius speaks into a cluster of microphones and addresses the press:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Be it known, As to us, to all the world, that Caius
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wears this war's garland And from this time, For what he did before Corioles, call him, With all the applause and clamor of the host, "Caius Martius Coriolanus!" (TO MARTIUS) Bear the addition nobly ever! The soldiers salute in a grim sort of chant:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Caius Martius Coriolanus! Coriolanus has reached the podium. An awkward beat. Cominius gestures for him to speak into the microphones. He tersely does so:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No more of this; it does offend my heart. Pray now, no more. An awkward silence. Cominius elegantly tries to covers the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, sir, your mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have, I know, petitioned all the gods For my prosperity. He kneels to her -- slowly, with great difficulty -- she lets him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nay, my good soldier, up. (he slowly rises) My gentle Martius, worthy Caius, and By deed-achieving honor newly named - What is it? - Coriolanus must I call thee? She laughs coquettishly, thoroughly upstaging her son. Then, almost an afterthought:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But, 0, thy wife... Coriolanus greets Virgilia with the clumsy and stiff formality that marks their marriage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My gracious silence, hail. An awkwardly tender kiss. He notes her tears. Reacts coldly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would thou have laughed had I come coffined home, That weeps to see me triumph? Ay, my dear, Such eyes the widows in Corioles wear, And mothers that lack sons.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, the gods crown thee!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (greets him warmly) And live you yet?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know not where to turn. 0, welcome home! And welcome, general. And you're welcome all!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A hundred thousand welcomes! Coriolanus is surrounded by well-wishers and political admirers. Volumnia and Menenius usher him along. We see the image from TV: The noble warrior returned home. Devoted family. Flags waving. The future golden.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And then the hard reality. Coriolanus' body is a battleground of scars. Some are livid and red, fresh and still oozing blood. Others are pale and blue, discolored and dead. His body is something monstrous. Stitched up. Patched together. Slashed around. Frankenstein's monster.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . He is leaning against a sink, stripped naked. His muscular if shattered body exposed. Volumnia sits and dresses her son's wounds. As she always has done. As she always will. It is a disturbing, intimate image.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The good Senators must be visited; From whom I have received not only greetings, But with them change of honors. He shifts painfully as she continues to treat one of his wounds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have lived To see inherited my very wishes And the buildings of my fancy. Only There's one thing wanting, which I doubt
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Our Rome will cast upon thee. He catches her eye in the mirror, very firm:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Know, good mother, I had rather be their servant in my way, Than sway with them in theirs. They stop when-- Virgilia enters. She stops in the doorway. It is embarrassing for her, as if she has interrupted two lovers. A long moment. She looks to her husband. To Volumnia. They stare back. There is no way she can compete with their intimacy. Surrendering, she silently goes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Virgilia wanders a long hallway, past a fine collection of antique Roman weaponry. She seems lost.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . She stops and opens a door, glances into her son's bedroom: Young Martius is asleep. Her eyes move across his room. The military toys. The little cadet uniform carefully hung. The polished boots waiting. All stern and joyless. Not like a child's room at all. Virgilia closes the door and continues down the long hallway, disappearing into darkness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darkened office. Brutus and Sicinius sit, heads together, focused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He cannot temperately transport his honors, but will Lose those he hath won.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I heard him swear, Were he to stand for Consul, never would
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Appear in the marketplace nor Showing, as the manner is, his wounds To the people, beg "their stinking breaths."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was his word.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brutus and Sicinius continue as they hurry to the Senate
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So it must fall out with him, Or our authorities at an end.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We must suggest to the people in what
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He still hath held them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peace...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . They enter the Senate Chamber...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brutus and Sicinius make their way to their seats as we hear:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.0.) It remains, As the main point of this our after- meeting, To gratify his noble service that Hath thus stood for his country... The interior of the grand Senate is an airy, sweeping chamber that suggests the Israeli Knesset or U.N. General Assembly. Again, classical symmetry is the rule with tiers of seats facing a central dais. An imposing piece of outdated modern art suggesting the might of Rome looms over the chamber like a bird of prey. Network TV cameras purr quietly from a corner. Menenius, Cominius, Coriolanus and several other politicos are seating at a central table on the dais, facing the rows of SENATORS. Menenius is standing at a podium, speaking into a microphone:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Therefore, please you, Most reverend and grave elders, to desire The present Consul, and last general In our well-found successes, to report A little of that worthy work performed By Caius Martius Coriolanus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Speak, good Cominius. General Cominius rises and moves to the podium. But then Coriolanus abruptly stands--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nay, keep your place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sit, Coriolanus. Never shame to hear What you have nobly done.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your honors' pardon. I had rather have my wounds to heal again Than hear say how I got them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pray now, sit down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I had rather have one scratch my head in
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When the alarum were struck than idly sit To hear my nothings monstered. Coriolanus moves across the dais and exits into a hallway. The door shuts after him. Menenius sighs. Nods to Cominius. Cominius moves to the podium and begins to read his speech from a Teleprompter. This all has the rehearsed quality of a campaign nomination speech.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The deeds of Coriolanus Should not be uttered feebly. It is held That valor is the chiefest virtue, and Most dignifies the haver. Alone he
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The mortal gate of the city, And struck Corioles like a planet, From face to foot He was a thing of blood... Brutus and Sicinius exchange a glance, bored by the political boilerplate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Meanwhile, Coriolanus stands in the service corridor beyond the chamber. Green industrial walls. Ugly fluorescent lights above. He leans against a wall, alone with his thoughts. Cominius' voice can be heard droning inside. Then Coriolanus glances up. A CUSTODIAN is pushing a garbage can down the long corridor. He stops when he sees Coriolanus. Coriolanus' cool, uncompromising stare makes the Custodian uneasy. He turns around and goes back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Coriolanus waits. His face strangely vacant. He flexes his wounded arm. It hurts. He hears Cominius finish. A good round of applause. He hears his name being cheered: "Coriolanus!" Coriolanus closes his eyes, steels himself, and then re- enters the chamber...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Menenius greets him and escorts him to the podium for his "acceptance speech."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Senate, Coriolanus, are well pleased To make thee Consul! Menenius steps back. A beat. Coriolanus stares at the Senators. At the TV cameras. He leans awkwardly into the podium microphone:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do owe them still My life and services. A beat. For an acceptance speech, rather terse. Menenius jumps in to salvage the moment:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It then remains That you do speak to the people.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do beseech you, Let me overleap that custom, for I cannot
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For my wounds' sake to give their suffrage. Please you that I may pass this doing. From the Senate floor, Sicinius jumps on this:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir, the people Must have their voices!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The Senators, led by Brutus, clamor their agreement. Tradition must be obeyed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (calming, to Coriolanus) Pray you, go fit you to the custom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is a part That I shall blush in acting, and might
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Be taken from the people. Menenius quickly turns off Coriolanus' microphone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark you that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To brag unto them "Thus I did, and thus!" Show them the unaching scars which I should hide, As if I had received them for the hire Of their breath only! Menenius sees Coriolanus is getting angry, this could be disastrous. He elegantly gestures for Cominius to escort Coriolanus out immediately -- as he addresses the Senators and TV cameras:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To our noble Consul Wish we all joy and honor! He applauds. The applause is taken up by the Senators. Some cheering as well for the hero of Rome The two Tribunes, however, are already whispering maliciously to other Senators. Menenius seems pleased with the general response. So far, so good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Volumnia is pleased as well. She sits, watching the events unfold on TV. The sound of the cheering fades as we go to...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The limousine winds through the pedestrian traffic toward the Roman marketplace. Coriolanus sits with Menenius. Coriolanus is both angry and embarrassed. He is wearing a sharp business suit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you not known The worthiest men have done it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Custom calls me to it. What custom wills, in all things should we do... What must I say? "Look, sir, my wounds. I got them in my country's service."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: O me, the gods! You must not speak like that. You must
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To think upon you--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Think upon me"? Hang 'em! I would they would forget me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll mar all! The limo stops. They are at the marketplace. The moment has come. Menenius takes a breath. Urges calm:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pray you, speak to them, I pray you, In wholesome manner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bid them wash their faces And keep their teeth clean. He leaves the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The commercial heart of Rome. A large town square, since antiquity used as a marketplace. But now it is filled with tatty stalls selling cheap purses and knock-off watches. Paltry fruit stands alongside shabby souvenir stalls. Advertising billboards surround and pollute the square -- SONY. COKE. NIKE. MCDONALDS -- obscuring any classical architecture that might have survived. Tamora and Cassius, the political activists, are in the crowd. They watch closely. Coriolanus slowly walks to the center of the marketplace. He stands, feeling ridiculous and not at all humble. He looks around. Waiting for something to happen. The CUSTOMERS and SHOPKEEPERS just look back at him. Some are curious. Some are amused. Some hostile and most indifferent. But no one approaches. Then Coriolanus understands. He must g to them: beg for votes. He prepares himself and then slowly moves through the various stalls, weaving in and out. Trying to maintain his dignity. He sees the Citizens from before and goes to them. We glimpse Brutus and Sicinius amongst the crowd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know the cause, sir, of my standing here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We do, sir. Tell us what hath brought you to it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mine own desert.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your own desert?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ay, but not mine own desire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How not your own desire?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, it was never my desire yet to trouble the poor with begging.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You must think, if we give you anything, we hope to gain by you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well then, I pray, your price of the Consulship?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The price is to ask it kindly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kindly, sir, I pray, let me have it. I have wounds to show you, which shall be yours in private Your good voice, sir. What say you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You shall have it, worthy sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A match, sir. There's in all two worthy voices begged. I have your alms. Adieu. Business done, so he thinks, Coriolanus crisply moves on. Cassius is not convinced.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But this is something odd. Coriolanus continues on. He sees a large JAMAICAN WOMAN with her CHILDREN, carrying plastic grocery bags, talking to a
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . He goes to them:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pray you now, if it may stand with the tune of your voices that I may be Consul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have deserved nobly of your country, and you have not deserved nobly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your enigma?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have been a scourge to her enemies; you have been a rod to her friends You have not indeed loved the common people.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You should account me the more virtuous that I have not been common in my love Therefore, beseech you, I may be Consul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We hope to find you our friend, and therefore give you our voices heartily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have received many wounds for your country.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will not seal your knowledge with showing them. I will make much of your voices, and so trouble you no farther.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The gods give you joy, sir, heartily! Coriolanus is warming to the task, it's easier than he thought. He moves to a central, open area and declares
direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For your voices Have done many things, some less, some more. Your voices! Indeed, I would be Consul.

direction.raw_text: He has done nobly, and cannot go without any honest man's voice!

direction.raw_text: Therefore let him be Consul!

direction.raw_text: Amen, amen. God save thee, noble Consul!

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There, Coriolanus.

direction.raw_text: Amen, sir. To my poor unworthy notice, He mocked us when he begged our voices.

direction.raw_text: No, it is his kind of speech; he did not mock us.

direction.raw_text: He should have showed us His marks of merit, wounds received for's country.

direction.raw_text: Why, so he did, I am sure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no! No one saw them!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (inciting the crowd) Was not this mockery? Brutus presses hard:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When he had no power, But was a petty servant to the state, He was your enemy, ever spake against Your liberties.

direction.raw_text: Did you perceive He did solicit you in free contempt When he did need your loves, and do you

direction.raw_text: That his contempt shall not be bruising

direction.raw_text: We will so! All Repent in their election! Cassius and Tamora lead the crowd. It is a terrifying spectacle of sudden mob rage, only a razor-thin edge to violence. Brutus and Sicinius watch, satisfied, like Robespierre and Saint Just looking over the bloody guillotine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coriolanus, dressed again in his familiar uniform, emerges from an antechamber with his comrade Titus. Menenius, General Cominius and several pro-Coriolanus Senators follow them. They stride down the corridor.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Spoke he of me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He did, my lord.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How? What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How often he had met you, sword to sword; That of all things upon the earth he
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your person most.

direction.raw_text: At Antium lives he?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At Antium.

direction.raw_text: I wish I had a cause to seek him there, To oppose his hatred fully. They hear the growing rumble of a crowd. Curious. They continue on and turn a corner to...

direction.raw_text: The central lobby of the Senate is an open, airy space. Through the glass doors at the front of the lobby an unruly crowd can be seen gathering. Police. Barricades. Sicinius and Brutus are waiting to intercept them.

direction.raw_text: Behold, these are the Tribunes of the people, The tongues of the common mouth.

direction.raw_text: Pass no further.

direction.raw_text: The matter?

direction.raw_text: Hath he not passed the nobles and the commons?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cominius, no. Coriolanus steps closer to Brutus. The mob sees him through the glass doors. The tension immediately increases.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have I had children's voices?

direction.raw_text: Tribunes, give way.

The police try to hold them back, keeping them away from the doors. The crowd presses in. We see Cassius and Tamora at the forefront, urging the crowd on.

direction.raw_text: Let's be calm--

direction.raw_text: Not in this heat, sir-- Coriolanus strides angrily toward the doors and exits-- The others follow--

direction.raw_text: Coriolanus launches himself into the crowd with blistering
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My nobler friends, I crave their pardons. For the mutable, rank-scented crowd, Let them regard me as I do not flatter, And therein behold themselves. I say again, In soothing them, we nourish against our
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The cockle of rebellion, insolence, sedition, Which we ourselves have ploughed for, sowed, and scattered, By mingling them with us!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, no more!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No more words, we beseech you-- The mob has surrounded them all by now. The police are getting nervous, eyes darting uneasily from the unruly crowd to the volatile men. This all has the potential of sparking to violence. We note a TV news crew moving into position, covering the action. Others film with cell phone cameras. We intercut some of this footage.

direction.raw_text: (to Coriolanus, provoking) You speak of the people As if you were a god to punish, not A man of their infirmity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It were well we let the people know it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Were I as patient as the midnight sleep, By Jove, it would be my mind!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is a mind That shall remain a poison where it is, Not poison any further.

direction.raw_text: "Shall remain"! Hear you this Triton of the minnows? Mark
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll give my reasons, More worthier than their voices! Menenius tries to pull him away, Coriolanus shakes free and continues the attack:

direction.raw_text: Come, enough!

direction.raw_text: Enough, with over-measure.

direction.raw_text: (calling to the crowd) Here's he that would take from you all your power! The crowd reacts angrily -- surging forward against the restraint of the police. We see grim RIOT POLICE marching into position. The crowd is not intimidated, they are spoiling for a fight. The Tribunes provoke the crowd even more, escalating and building the fever:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are at point to lose your liberties! Martius would have all from you, Martius, Whom late you have named for Consul.

direction.raw_text: True! The people are the city!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We do here pronounce, upon the part of the people, Martius is worthy of present DEATH! A huge roar from the mob. Panic and violence building. Fast
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Guards, seize him!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I'll die here!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lay hands upon him!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to the crowd)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! At his cue-- The civil violence threatened from the opening moments of this story finally EXPLODES-- 53. With Cassius and Tamora in the forefront, the crowd attacks

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The mob fights back with anything at hand -- some are armed with clubs and knives, others snatch up garbage cans and newspaper vending machines, throwing them, smashing windows, battling the police, kicking and punching and screaming-- It is civil disobedience. But it is also drunken, thug violence. Terrifying in its intensity-- Menenius gets Titus and Cominius to hustle Coriolanus away--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go, get you to your house! Be gone, away! All will be naught else--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come, sir, along with us-- They hurry Coriolanus away-- The Riot Police, outnumbered, start firing TEAR GAS into the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: news crew filming-- Chaotic, flurried violence-- Shaky TV images, cell phone video-- Choking, acrid gas-- It is a terrifying descent into public madness as all order breaks down. Rome is bloody.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Menenius and the Tribunes are gathered in a darkened office for some high-stakes politicking. Tamora, her face bloody from the riot, is with them. So too some supporters on either side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Consul! What Consul?

direction.raw_text: The Consul Coriolanus.

direction.raw_text: He Consul?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is decreed He dies tonight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's a disease that must be cut away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: he's a limb that has but a disease: Mortal, to cut it off; to cure it, easy. What has he done to Rome that's worth his death? Eh? Killing our enemies?! He sees that his words are having some effect, he presses the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The blood he hath lost -- He dropped it for his country. Some in the room murmur agreement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll hear no more--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Consider this: he has been bred in the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Since he could draw a sword, and is ill

direction.raw_text: In graceful language Give me leave, I'll go to him, and undertake to bring
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Noble tribunes, It is the humane way.

direction.raw_text: The other course Will prove too bloody, and the end of it Unknown to the beginning. Sicinius is about to retort when Brutus stops him. Brutus assents, assuming the voice of reason:

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you bring not Martius, we'll proceed In our first way.

direction.raw_text: I'll bring him to you. He goes quickly. Brutus turns to Sicinius and Tamora and begins to quietly explain his plan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coriolanus strides angrily down a long corridor, in and out of shafts of light, seething to Titus:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let them pull all about mine ears,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Death on the wheel or at wild horses' heels, Yet will I still be thus to them--!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I muse my mother Does not approve me further! He slams through a door to the living room...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And stomps to confront his mother, who is currently conspiring with Menenius and a few Senators.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Volumnia, angrily) I talk of you! Why did you wish me milder? Would you
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: False to my nature? Rather say I play The man I am! She is equally tough with him, not giving an inch, snapping
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: sir, sir, sir, I would have had you put your power well on, Before you had worn it out.

direction.raw_text: Let go!

direction.raw_text: You might have been enough the man you are, With striving less to be so!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let them hang!

direction.raw_text: Av, and burn too! Her outraged fury matches his. Overpowers his.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come, come, you have been too rough, something too rough. You must return and mend it. Coriolanus turns away.

direction.raw_text: Pray, be counseled. I have a heart as little apt as yours, But yet a brain that leads my use of
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To better vantage.

direction.raw_text: Well said, noble woman!
direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Return to the Tribunes.

direction.raw_text: Well, what then? What then?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Repent what you have spoke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For them? I cannot do it to the gods. Must I then do it to them?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are too absolute, Though therein you can never be too noble.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (upset, walking away) Why force you this? She pursues him:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because that now it lies you on to speak To the people, not by your own instruction, Nor by the matter which your heart prompts you, But with such words that are but
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your tongue, though but bastards and
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of no allowance to your bosom's truth... She moves closer to him. Her voice lower. A sort of seduction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would dissemble with my nature where My fortunes and my friends at stake
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I should do so in honor... She is very close now. Whispering. She touches him gently, like a lover.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am in this your wife, your son, These senators, the nobles And you. A long beat. All are silent, watching her spin her web.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I prithee now, my son, Go and say to them Thou art their soldier, and being bred in
direction.name: direction
