direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thyself, forsooth, hereafter theirs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This but done, even as she speaks, Why their hearts were yours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Prithee now, Go, and be ruled... (laughing to him) Although I know thou hadst rather Follow thine enemy in a fiery gulf Than flatter him in a bower. Coriolanus smiles. A genuinely sweet moment between them. Cominius enters with several other political supporters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir, it is fit You make strong party, or defend yourself By calmness or by absence. All's in anger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only fair speech.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think it will serve, if he Can thereto frame his spirit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He must -- and will. (TO CORIOLANUS) Prithee now, say you will, and go about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With base tongue give my noble heart A lie that it must bear? . Well, I will do it. But he is still agitated. Volumnia shares a concerned glance with Menenius.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Away, my disposition, and possess me Some harlot's spirit. A beggar's tongue Make motion through my lips, and my armed knees, Who bowed but in my stirrup, bend like
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That hath charity received! The thought of begging is too much, he rejects it, breaking
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will not do it! Lest I cease to honor mine own truth And by my body's action teach my mind A most inherent baseness. Volumnia snarls at him, exasperated, building to a thunder that dwarfs his:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At thy choice, then! To beg of thee, it is my more dishonor Than thou of them. Come all to ruin! Let Thy mother rather feel thy pride than
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thy dangerous stoutness, for I mock at
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With as biq heart as thou! Do as you like! The words echo. It is as if he has been slapped. His resolve vanishes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pray, be content... Mother, I am going, chide me no more. He awaits her approval. She will not yet grant it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, I am going... Commend me to my wife. I'll return Consul, Or never trust to what my tongue can do In the way of flattery further. She graciously bows to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do your will. Then she kisses him. And she goes. Like a queen. Volumnia triumphant. Always. Then a shocking hard cut to:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A crowded TV studio. The audience stands are filling up. Television cameras. Lights. Heavy security. On the stage: the set for a chat show. Translight of a city skyline behind the set. Two standing microphones. At the side of the set, Sicinius and Brutus are conspiring with the two citizen activists, Cassius and Tamora:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In this point charge him home: that he
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tyrannical power. If he evade us there, Enforce him with his envy to the people.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you a catalogue Of all the voices that we have procured Set down by the poll?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have; it's ready.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When the people hear me say "It shall be
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the right and strength of the Commons," be it either For death, for fine, or banishment, then let them, If I say "Fine," cry "Fine!" - if "Death," cry "Death!"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We shall inform them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cassius and Tamora hurry off to instruct and manipulate the crowd as best they can. They mix with the audience in the stands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A gloomy but resolved Coriolanus walks with Cominius and Menenius between the tiers of audience, on the way to the set.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To answer mildly, for they are prepared With accusations, as I hear, more strong Than are upon you yet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The word is "mildly." Pray you, let us go. Let them accuse me by invention, I Will answer in mine honor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ay, but mildly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, mildly be it then. Mildly! Coriolanus steels himself as they emerge from between the stands and head toward the set.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: news crews are waiting. Blinding lights snap on. The crowd, on seeing Coriolanus, lets out a ROAR. Deafening and savage. We see Cassius and Tamora moving through the crowd, instigating, convincing, imploring. Coriolanus ignores it all. Imperious to the end. Brutus and Sicinius wait on the set.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispers to Sicinius) Put him to choler straight. Coriolanus and his supporters move to the stage. Coriolanus glares at the Tribunes. The TV crews take up position. Menenius gestures for Coriolanus to step to the microphone, whispering to him:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Calmly, I do beseech you. Coriolanus steps to the microphone. Brutus gestures for the crowd to quiet down. We see bits of this scene through the monitors on the TV cameras. When the crowd is silent, Coriolanus begins to make a
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The honored gods-- But his voice echoes badly with reverb. Menenius adjusts the microphone. Coriolanus begins again, quickly and by rote:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The honored gods Keep Rome in safety, and the chairs of
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Supplied with worthy men. Plant love among us. Throng our large temples with the shows of peace, And not our streets with war.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amen, amen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A noble wish. His boilerplate speech over, Coriolanus turns to Sicinius who is at the other standing microphone:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shall I be charged no further than this present? Must all determine here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do demand, If you submit you to the people's voices.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am content.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Volumnia watches the proceedings closely on TV. She is pleased with her son's performance so far.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Menenius, ever the People's Friend, steps to the microphone:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lo, citizens, he says he is content. The warlike service he has done,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Upon the wounds his body bears, which
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like graves in the holy churchyard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (uncomfortable with this) Scratches with briers, Scars to move laughter only.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aufidius sits with several of his officers, leaning forward, watching the drama unfold on TV.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Consider further, That when he speaks not like a citizen, You find him like a soldier. Do not take His rougher accents for malicious sounds, But, as I say, such as become a soldier. Coriolanus cuts in, his impatience getting the better of him:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is the matter That being passed for Consul with full voice, I am so dishonored that the very hour You take it off again?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We charge you that you have contrived to
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From Rome all seasoned office, and to
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yourself into a power tyrannical (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (the coup de grace) For which you are a traitor to the people. Coriolanus responds, a cobra striking:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How? Traitor?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nay, temperately! Your promise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The fires in the lowest hell fold in the people! Call me their traitor, thou injurious Tribune!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark you this, people?! The crowd responds, egged on by Cassius and Tamora. A murmur of voices, a chant growing, "Traitor traitor traitor..." Brutus cleverly plays the reasonable voice, knowing his words will further rile Coriolanus:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But since he hath Served well for Rome--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you prate of service?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I talk of that, that know it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You?! I'll know no further. Let them pronounce death, exile, Flaying, pent to linger But with a grain a day - I would not buy Their mercy at the price of one fair word!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Volumnia watches, alarmed now. She knows this rage will prove to be disastrous for her son.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sicinius seizes the moment to destroy Coriolanus, barking into the microphone:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the name of the people And in the power of us the Tribunes, we, Even from this instant, banish him our city! In the people's name, I say IT SHALL BE SO! Well-rehearsed by Cassius and Tamora, many in the crowd respond with a fierce cry:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It shall be so! It shall be so! Let him away!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's banished! IT SHALL BE SO!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It shall be so! It shall be so! It shall be so...! Cassius and Tamora keep the crowd at a fever pitch-- They keep chanting and railing-- A building seismic rumble--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hear me, my masters, and my common friends--!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's sentenced. No more hearing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me speak! The crowd's fury is building-- It is all about to erupt--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's no more to be said, but he is
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As enemy to the people and his country.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It shall be so! It shall be so! It shall be so...!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His rage is volcanic-- He SLAMS the standing microphone away-- His dragon's ROAR silences the entire studio--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! A collective intake of breath-- The crowd is stunned--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whose breath I hate As reek of the rotten fens, whose loves I PRIZE As the dead carcasses of unburied men That do corrupt my air... (each word an attack)
direction.name: direction

result.heading: CORIOLANUS YOU COMMON CRY OF CURS

direction.raw_text: ! The crowd is silent. No one dares to even breathe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Volumnia watches, frozen, breathless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Aufidius stands, riveted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here remain with your uncertainty. Let every feeble rumor shake your hearts! Your enemies, with nodding of their plumes, Fan you into despair! Have the power
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To banish your defenders, till at length Your ignorance - which finds not till it feels, (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Making but reservation of yourselves; Still your own foes - deliver you As most abated captives to some nation That won you without blows! A beat. The TV cameras hum. The crowd is silent. Menenius and the others watch in amazement. Coriolanus slowly takes one last, long look at the people of Rome.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Despising, For you, the city, thus I turn my back. He turns and slowly walks toward one of the tunnels leading from the studio. The crowd follows every step with their eyes. He stops. Turns back. Steel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a world elsewhere. And he goes down the tunnel. Disappearing from view. A silent beat. Then, a chilling cry of absolutely Jacobin bloodlust from the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The people's enemy is gone! The crowd SCREAMS their approval. The SAVAGE CRY echoes around the studio. The echoing roar takes us to...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The outskirts of Rome are an urban wasteland. Abandoned factories. Rusting cars. Overgrown vacant lots. Collapsing advertising billboards. There is a lonely gas station in the distance, its neon sign glowing a lurid green in the gray dawn light. We are at a Roman checkpoint on the highway into the city. A guardhouse and barrier. Some barbed wire barricades. Bored soldiers. Several cars pull up to the checkpoint. Two Roman security SUVs. Menenius' familiar limousine. And Volumnia's enormous Bentley. Security Guards climb out of their vehicle, light cigarettes and chat with the soldiers manning the checkpoint. Menenius, Titus and Cominius climb from Menenius' limousine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Meanwhile, inside the Bentley, Coriolanus is comforting his wife and mother:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come, leave your tears. A brief farewell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With many heads butts me away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Volumnia has tears in her eyes as well. Coriolanus is surprisingly unsentimental and tough with her:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nay, mother, Where is your ancient courage?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now the red pestilence strike all trades in Rome, And occupations perish!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nay, mother, I shall be loved when I am lacked. She nods to him, she has regained her composure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Only then do they climb from the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coriolanus takes his leave:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bid me farewell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Farewell, Martius.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cominius, droop not, adieu. I'll do well yet. He goes to Menenius, who is genuinely distraught. For all his political machinations, he truly cares for Coriolanus. Coriolanus is moved to see Menenius so emotional.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thou old and true Menenius, Thy tears are salter than a younger man's, And venomous to thine eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I could shake off but seven years I'd go with thee every foot. They embrace. Then Coriolanus knows it is time to go. He picks up a traveling bag and slings it over his shoulder. Looks back at his friends and family. A beat. A certain darkness creeps into his expression. An ominous resolve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You shall hear from me still. He turns and looks to the distance. Miles and miles of wasteland and desolation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . His future.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I go alone, Like to a lonely dragon. He strides off. The soldiers manning the checkpoint raise the barrier. Coriolanus walks under it. And begins walking down the long highway away from Rome. The only sound is the cold, lonely moan of the wind. We fade to...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coriolanus' exile. We see his long odyssey. It is a grueling physical journey -- and also something of a spiritual challenge. He is solitary and without comfort: vulnerable to the elements and also to the demons of his own psyche. We see him as... He walks along the barren highway. Trash piled along the road. A car zooms past. Whoosh. He is lost in dust... Blazing heat, like a furnace, as he trudges over desert terrain. Burning oil wells blacken the sky in the distance... Isolated, within himself, as he walks past the detritus of war a burned out tank a mountain of rusted artillery shells skeletons bleached in the sun... His clothes are dusty and dirty now. A sandstorm. He wraps a scarf around his head, like a burnoose. Only his eyes visible now... A gypsy boy in tattered clothing riding a white horse passes him. The boy looks at him intently as he passes... We get a sense of him moving into different terrain, up into a mountain range, climbing... Then descending. Pouring rain. Lightning sparking. He is almost a Romantic figure now. Byronic. Wrapped in a cloak against the wildness of nature; the chiaroscuro flashes of light illuminating his haunted eyes...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . We end at...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coriolanus stands. Like a statue. All his life in his blazing eyes. He is staring at a small town in the distance. We see a sign: ANTIUM. His destination since he began. The home of his nemesis, the hated Aufidius. He begins to walk to the town.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Meanwhile, back in Rome, Brutus and Sicinius are having lunch at their usual hangout. They see Volumnia entering the restaurant, pulling Virgilia after her. An ambush. She heads toward the Tribunes. Volumnia's eyes have the grim intensity of a predator. She looks strangely wild.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here comes his mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (prepares to go) Let's not meet her. They say she's mad. Volumnia stalks up to them:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: you're well met. The hoarded plague of
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Requite your love! The Tribunes try to leave, she won't let them:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will you be gone?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You shall stay too. I would I had the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To say so to my husband.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you mad?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ay, fool, is that a shame? Note but this,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hadst thou craft To banish him that struck more blows for
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Than thou hast spoken words?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (trying to escape) 0 blessed heavens... Volumnia is creating a scene. Heads are turning. She continues her attack on Sicinius, but is distracted and
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: More noble blows than ever thou wise words, And for Rome's good. I'll tell thee what -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nay -- but thou shalt stay too -- I would
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Were in Arabia, and thy tribe before him, His good sword in his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What then?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What then? He'd make an end of thy posterity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bastards and all. Menenius has entered the bar, seeing the trouble he goes to them, tries to calm Volumnia:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come, come, peace...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pray, let us go. He tries to leave the bar. Volumnia stops him for final attack, something like a curse in its power:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, pray, sir, get you gone. You have done a brave deed. Ere you go,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This lady's husband here, this, do you see?!-- Whom you have banished, does exceed you all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, well, we'll leave you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why stay we to be baited With one that wants her wits?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would the gods had nothing else to do But to confirm my curses! Menenius gently restrains Volumnia and the Tribunes finally escape the bar. Volumnia takes a breath, controls herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Could I meet 'em But once a day, it would unclog my heart Of what lies heavy to it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have told them home; And, by my troth, you have cause. You'll sup with me? She turns to him. A cold and killing fire in her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anger's my meat. I sup upon myself, And so shall starve with feeding. She takes Virgilia's hand and drags her out. Menenius watches. Saddened. Once proud Volumnia, reduced to this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Antium is an old Volscian city gone to seed. It is Latin in flavor, something like Havana. There is life to the place, a certain humid vitality. Someone is singing in a bar. Old men are playing dominos on a patio. Flickering TV and radio babel from terraced apartment buildings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Coriolanus, his face still shrouded in the burnoose, like a Hamas soldier, moves through the streets. He takes in the life of the town as he walks. Studying the faces of the Volscians around him. Coriolanus sees a heavily-guarded apartment building at the end of the street. Jeeps and SOLDIERS. Coriolanus approaches with stealth, moving in and out of shadows along the street, ducking into doorways and alleys, taking advantage of the darkness. He stops. Steps into the shadows. For he sees... Aufidius. Walking with a few of his officers. Aufidius is beloved in Antium. He has an easy manner with the people. He stops and chats. Laughs with them. He dances for a moment with a little girl. Coriolanus watches from the shadows, his expression complex. There is real envy . Aufidius has such a comfortable way with the common people, he's natural, unaffected. Aufidius jokes with the little girl's parents for a moment and then moves on. Coriolanus watches Aufidius and his men go into an apartment building. He scans the building with the eye of a Special Forces soldier. He sees that the soldiers guarding the building are bored, it is perfunctory work. Two YOUNG WOMEN, perhaps hookers, move past the front of the building, flirting with the soldiers. The soldiers call and whistle to them, delighted. Coriolanus uses this distraction to slip into the shadows behind the soldiers and sneak into the building...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coriolanus moves again with stealth, heading toward what is clearly the center of the action: a noisy room on the second floor. The doorway is guarded by two serious GUARDS. These are not the bored soldiers out front, these are grim and intense warriors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Coriolanus considers his course. Decides. Takes a breath. Focuses. He is like ice now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A steady stride-- He walks right up to the Guards-- Before they can even respond-- He punches one HARD in the throat -- the Guard recoils, gasping for air-- Simultaneously, Coriolanus SLAMS his other hand violently over the entire face of the second Guard -- grabbing his face firmly and SHOVING him back into the door-- So hard that the door slams aside-- And Coriolanus shoves the Guard into--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aufidius is having dinner with some of his men, their wives and some children-- The soldiers bolt up, upsetting the table, smashing dishes -- pulling guns -- alarmed-- As Coriolanus powers in, still holding the second Guard by
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He flings the Guard aside-- Aufidius and his men, all pointing weapons at Coriolanus, are stunned. A long beat. Coriolanus' face is still masked by the burnoose. Only his cold eyes are visible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whence comes thou? What wouldst thou? Thy name? Coriolanus does not respond.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Aufidius is growing uneasy. His men are tense, ready to open fire at any second.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Speak, man! What's thy name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A name unmusical to the Volscians' ears, And harsh in sound to thine. The other Guard from outside, and several other soldiers, rush in. Weapons drawn, surrounding Coriolanus. He doesn't move a muscle. Aufidius, intrigued by the stranger's courage, waves his men off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Say, what's thy name? Thou has a grim appearance .What's thy name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Know'st thou me yet?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know thee not Thy name? Finally, Coriolanus removes his burnoose. His face is exposed. The Volscians are stunned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My name is Caius Martius, who hath done To thee particularly and to all the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Great hurt and mischief; thereto witness
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My surname Coriolanus. The Volscians look to Aufidius, very nervous, unsure how to proceed. Aufidius just stares back at Coriolanus, staggered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only that name remains. Aufidius doesn't understand. Coriolanus explains:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The cruelty and envy of the people, Who have all forsook me, hath devoured the rest, And suffered me by the voice of slaves to
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whooped out of Rome. Now this extremity Hath brought me to thy hearth, not out of
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mistake me not - to save my life; for if I had feared death, of all the men in the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would have avoided thee, but in mere spite, To be full quit of those my banishers, Stand I before thee here. Coriolanus dares to take a step toward Aufidius-- The Volscians react. Guns are raised, fingers tight on triggers, an instant from opening fire-- Coriolanus carefully holds out his arms. He's unarmed. Aufidius nods to his men. They hold their fire. Coriolanus slowly crosses the room toward Aufidius. Step by step. Their eyes are locked. Nothing else in the world exists.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will fight Against my cankered country with the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of all the under fiends. But if thou Dares not this, then I present My throat to thee and to thy ancient malice... Coriolanus stops right in front of Aufidius and slowly, carefully, undoes his collar. Exposing his naked throat. Bending back his head. Ready for execution.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Which not to cut would show thee but a fool, Since I have ever followed thee with hate, And cannot live but to thy shame unless It be to do thee service. A long beat. Aufidius stares at Coriolanus. The Volscians watch, eyes wide, too tense to do anything now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Aufidius just continues to stare at Coriolanus. Eyes locked. Coriolanus blinks some sweat from his eyes. This tiny, human response sparks something in Aufidius.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Martius Martius Each word thou hast spoke hath weeded from my heart A root of ancient envy. He offers his hand. Coriolanus takes it. Aufidius continues to hold him by the hand, rather intensely, speaking low:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me twine Mine arms about that body. He embraces Coriolanus. Aufidius' men finally relax. Weapons are lowered. Relieved glances exchanged. Some of the Volscians, though, are clearly suspicious of Coriolanus. They watch Aufidius and Coriolanus, concerned. Aufidius still can't quite believe his ancient enemy is now his newest ally.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I loved the maid I married; never man Sighed truer breath. But that I see thee here, Thou noble thing, more dances my rapt
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Than when I first my wedded mistress saw Bestride my threshold. Coriolanus glances to him, perhaps a little disturbed or embarrassed by the intensity of Aufidius' words. Aufidius steps away from him, gestures for Coriolanus to sit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why, thou Mars, I tell thee, We have a power on foot, and I had
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Once more to hew thy target from thy brawn, (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Or lose mine arm for it. Thou hast beat
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twelve several times, and I have nightly
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dreamt of encounters 'twixt thyself and me. Aufidius continues quietly, almost whispering:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Worthy Martius, Had we no quarrel else to Rome, but that Thou art thence banished, we would muster
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From twelve to seventy, and, pouring war Into the bowels of ungrateful Rome, Like a bold flood, overbear it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coriolanus sits, naked. He has finally washed off the layers of dirt from his journey. An old woman is using an electric razor to shave his head. Aufidius is standing in the doorway to the room. Watching. His eyes move over Coriolanus' body, adding up the scars and wounds. A pause. Then Aufidius goes to the old woman. Takes the razor from her. She goes. Aufidius continues to shave Coriolanus' head himself. It is a deeply personal act, even intimate Yet Aufidius employs the same methodical rhythms as when he was sharpening his knife at the opening of the story.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Volscian military command center. Maps, recon photos and radio equipment. Stacks of grenade launchers and arms. Aufidius' CAPTAINS and AIDES wait alongside some bedraggled Volsce POLITICIANS in ill-fitting suits. Aufidius ushers Coriolanus in:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: come, go in, And take our friendly senators by the hands. Coriolanus shakes hands with the politicians:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You bless me, gods. Then Aufidius takes him to a huge military map laid out on a pool table. Rome and her territories. Strategic markers denote Roman forces and Volscian forces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Therefore, most absolute sir, if thou
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The leading of thine own revenges, take The one half of my commission. The Volscian soldiers and politicos are shocked. Aufidius is giving Coriolanus command of half his forces!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And set down--- As best thou art experienced, since thou
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thy country's strength and weakness--- thine own ways, Whether to knock against the gates of Rome, Or rudely visit them in parts remote, To fright them ere destroy. Aufidius looks at Coriolanus hard. There it is. The gauntlet is thrown down. Coriolanus will have to completely betray Rome: expose her military weaknesses, tell her secrets. For all his neurotic intensity, Aufidius is a shrewd man. Coriolanus nods and turns to the battle map, moving various markers around to show Rome's defensive positions. Aufidius watches him with Machiavellian calm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Several weeks later, back in Rome, politics go on as usual. Menenius is passing the Tribunes' table. They josh with him:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is this Menenius?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Tis he,'tis he! 0, he is grown most kind of late. Hail sir!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hail to you both.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is not much missed, but with his friends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All's well, and might have been much
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He could have temporized.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where is he, hear you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nay, I hear nothing. His mother and his
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hear nothing from him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Caius Martius was A worthy officer in the war, but insolent, Overcome with pride, ambitious past all thinking,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think not so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And Rome sits safe and still without him. They are distracted when people begin talking loudly, alarmed, at the bar. They hush each other and watch the TV over the bar. Something has happened. On the TV: a SPECIAL REPORT. Breaking News. A scroll across the bottom of the screen reads "The Volscians On The March?"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reports the Volsces with two several
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are entered in the Roman territories, And with the deepest malice of the war Destroy what lies before them...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The whole bar is growing quiet now. All watching the TV, which shows grainy indistinct images -- like cell phone pictures -- of troops and tanks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Tis Aufidius, Who, hearing of our Martius' banishment, Thrusts forth his horns again into the world.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come, what talk you of Martius?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It cannot be the Volsces dare break with us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The nobles in great earnestness are going All to the Senate House. Some news is
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That turns their countenances... (he listens to his ear piece for a second) Yes, the first report is seconded, and more, More fearful, is delivered. The TV picture switches to a flustered TV REPORTER outside the Senate. A lot of nervous activity behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is spoke freely out of many mouths - How probable I do not know - that Martius Has ioined with Aufidius-- There is an audible gasp in the bar -- quickly silenced and hushed so all can hear the TV:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: --He leads a power against Rome, And vows revenge as spacious as between The youngest and oldest thing. Something close to terror on the faces of the politicos. Menenius, without a word, goes. He does not want to believe this is possible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Virgilia lies on her bed. On the TV an imbedded WAR CORRESPONDENT is giving an update, intercut with shaky and unclear images of the Volscian army on the move:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A fearful army, led by Caius Martius Associated with Aufidius, rages Upon our territories, and have already Overborne their way, consumed with fire,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What lay before them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Volumnia sits, almost frozen, smoking, watching the TV. Her emotions are deep and dark. Her son, to her the model of all Roman virtues, has betrayed his country.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Martius has joined with the Volscians - He is their god. He leads them like Boys pursuing summer butterflies Or butchers killing flies. Close up on Volumnia's face. She gives away practically nothing. She takes a slow drag on her cigarette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Urban industrial wasteland. Old factories and abandoned warehouses. Broken asphalt. Smashed windows. The Volscians have set up camp here. On the decaying fringes of the city. We see military hardware. Guns. Missile launchers. Armored vehicles. Soldiers are cleaning weapons, cooking meals, sleeping, playing video games. Then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . An incongruous sight... An old barber chair floats past. Moving across the blue sky. Carried overhead by a group of Volscian soldiers. But there is something different about these Volscian soldiers. They have altered their uniforms into something pagan and primitive. All have shaved heads. Many have face tattoos or wear striking war paint. It is like something from LORD OF THE FLIES. They set the barber chair down outside an abandoned factory. This shattered and abandoned factory is Coriolanus' domain. It is decorated with human skulls. The CAMP BARBER, a fat man in a greasy butcher's apron, begins to strop his razor. Hard core young soldiers line up to have their heads shaved. They are Coriolanus' ACOLYTES. There is no sign of Coriolanus himself. Aufidius and his LIEUTENANT stand on the fringes, disturbed by the strange cult of personality that has grown up around Coriolanus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do they still fly to Coriolanus?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do not know what witchcraft's in him,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your soldiers use him as the grace before meat, Their talk at table, and their thanks at end. And you are darkened in this action, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He bears himself more proud, Even to my person, than I thought he
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When first I did embrace him. They turn and walk to the building where Aufidius is
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir, I beseech you, think you he'll carry Rome?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think he'll be to Rome As is the osprey to the fish, who takes
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By sovereignty of nature. Aufidius nods to the guards outside his quarters and enters with his Lieutenant...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A shattered building. Old graffiti on the walls. Weapons. Maps. Aufidius' gear. Aufidius sits on his cot, deep in thought. He pulls a folded bit of paper from his pocket. Carefully and lovingly unfolds it. He has been carrying this paper for months. We realize it is the glossy magazine cover with the picture of Coriolanus that Aufidius tore out earlier. He gazes at the picture, his fingers smoothing the paper, tracing the contours of Coriolanus' face...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whether t'was pride, Whether defect of judgement, Or whether nature, Not to be other than one thing, Made him feared, So hated, and so banished. A beat as he studies the picture. His lieutenant watches him closely, disturbed by Aufidius' obsession with Coriolanus.
direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rome is at war now, so the room is busy and tense. Maps and video footage chart the enemy's progress. Soldiers confer urgently outside the door. Menenius stands with the two Tribunes, Brutus and Sicinius. With them are several SENATORS and GENERALS. Menenius snaps angrily:

Menenius and the others crowd around him, waiting for his report. Titus sits, takes a moment to pull himself together, and then reports with the grim severity of a death sentence:

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Roman checkpoint on the desolate highway. A formidable military presence here now: soldiers, heavy weapons, tanks. Volscian troops and a jeep can be seen down the highway. We see Menenius' limousine pull up. He and General Cominius climb out. Menenius is out of place in his trim business suit: a politician among soldiers. Menenius steels himself then passes through the Roman checkpoint. He walks down the highway toward the distant Volscian troops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Menenius is blindfolded, roughly pulled by two Volscian soldiers. We hear some of the soldiers hooting at him. We stay close on Menenius' blindfolded face, sharing his feeling of disorientation and suspense. The Volscians drag him into the abandoned factory--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Finally his guards stop him and pull off his blindfold--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coriolanus. Transformed. And terrifying. He is no longer Roman. He is not Volscian. He is, as Titus said, "a kind of nothing." He sits in the barber chair. His head is completely shaved. His face is marked with martial face painting. These striking totemic markings also cover his scarred body. He is primitive. Inhuman. Like a dragon. The Angel of Death. His young warrior Acolytes -- similarly shaved and painted -- are gathered around him; his personal bodyguard and cult. A long beat as Menenius stares at his friend, stunned at the pagan metamorphosis. Coriolanus just gazes back at him. Menenius finally pulls himself together and approaches, with
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The glorious gods sit in hourly synod about thy particular prosperity, and love thee no worse than thy old friend Menenius does! 0 Martius, Martius! He steps forward to hug Coriolanus. Two of the Acolytes stop him. He can approach no further. Menenius accepts this. No matter. He is completely confident he will be able to manipulate his protege. He always has in the past.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thou art preparing fire for us. Look thee, here's water to quench it. I was hardly moved to come to thee, but being assured none but myself could move thee, I have been blown out of your gates with sighs, and conjure thee to pardon Rome.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . A long beat. Menenius waits for an answer. Grows uneasy. Then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How? . Away?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wife mother child I know not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are servanted to others. Menenius can't believe this cold response--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Therefore be gone. His frigid eyes slice into Menenius:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another word, Menenius, I will not hear thee speak. Menenius stares at him, shaken to the core. The Guards pull Menenius away. Coriolanus doesn't even glance at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Back at the Roman checkpoint, Menenius strides toward his limousine. He has been deeply shaken by his interaction with the transformed Coriolanus. General Cominius follows urgently, Menenius doesn't stop:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This Martius is grown from man to dragon. He has wings; he's more than a creeping thing. He stops at his limo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . A beat. He turns back to Cominius. We see the pain in Menenius' eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is no more mercy in him than there is milk in a male tiger. He climbs into his limo. Shuts the door. The limousine drives off, sending up a cloud of dust that swirls around Cominius.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Menenius sits in the back of his limo as it speeds back to Rome. The rejection by Coriolanus has wounded him. Also he is plagued by guilt. He helped create this monster. He pushed Coriolanus into politics. And now Coriolanus has lost his soul, even his humanity, and Rome is to be put to the sword. All his fault. This preys on him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Menenius' limousine pulls over by an isolated set of railroad tracks. Weeds springing up. Battered advertising posters. An old chain link fence. Menenius climbs out of the car and walks along the tracks. Thinking. He stops. He sits on the railroad tracks. Pulls out a little pocket knife and, in the Roman fashion, efficiently slits his wrists. He stares out over the hideous landscape. Blood begins to pool around his stylish shoes. From afar we see him, sitting on the railroad tracks, alone and forlorn in this surreal urban wasteland, like a Samuel Beckett character. He slumps over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Menenius is dead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The red glow of dusk is shining through the cracked and dusty windows. Coriolanus, still in the barber chair, broods silently. Aufidius sits nearby, watching him. The visit from Menenius is troubling Coriolanus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My partner in this action, You must report to the Volscian lords how

direction.raw_text: I have borne this business. Aufidius is curiously formal in his response, the estrangement he feels toward Coriolanus growing:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only their ends You have respected; stopped your ears
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Volumnia, Virgilia and Young Martius stride past the soldiers and mountains of military hardware. Volumnia leads, pulling the others by the hand. Some of the soldiers whistle. Some spit. Others laugh and make lascivious noises. Many just watch with grim dislike. Volumnia appears to be completely impervious to the whistles and cruel taunts. Her head is high, back straight, eagle eye forward. She was never more a Roman patrician.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . She is magnificent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coriolanus stands as Volumnia, Virgilia and Young Martius are led into the factory. He tries to register nothing, assuming a sort of glacial calm. Volumnia and the others stop -- taking in Coriolanus' savage new demeanor and appearance -- taking in the Acolytes and pagan totems. Volumnia just stands, peering sternly at her son. As if daring him not to crumble before her. He doesn't. Aufidius watches everything closely. It is Virgilia, finally, who bravely approaches:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My lord and husband-- He stop her, almost a warning, with:

direction.raw_text: These eyes are not the same I wore in Rome.

direction.raw_text: The sorrow that delivers us thus changed Makes you think so.

direction.raw_text: Best of my flesh, Forgive my tyranny, but do not say For that "Forgive our Romans." She shows great courage. Stepping forward and kissing him deeply. A long kiss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a kiss Long as my exile, sweet as my revenge. It is a perverse response. In his monomaniacal imagination, his wife's kiss is obsessively equated with his revenge on Rome. He finally moves to Volumnia, simply can't resist her orbital pull.

direction.raw_text: You gods I prate, And the most noble mother of the world Leave unsaluted. Sink, my knee, in the earth. He kneels before her. It is done with a sense of duty and protocol, not affection.

direction.raw_text: Down! Let us shame him with our knees! She claws at the dirt -- like Hecuba -- keening -- a shocking explosion of raw emotion -- almost an incantation:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Down! An end! This is the last. So we will home to Rome, And die among our neighbors. Nay, behold! This boy, that cannot tell what he would

direction.raw_text: Than thou hast to deny it. She remains kneeling, panting for air. Coriolanus looks at her. His noble mother. Clawing in the dirt like an animal. Filthy. Despairing. Her face wet with tears. She looks back up at him. She senses she has failed. It's over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come, let us go. She rises slowly, her age showing. Her spirit broken. Or seeming so. She stares at Coriolanus as she rips off the Roman Eagle medal she wears and flings it to the ground. The blood red sky of sunset behind her reflects her passion as she summons up all her strength for a lacerating and icy

Like a great building crumbling. Like fissures cutting across marble. Emotion floods into him. He lunges forward and grabs her hand. Volumnia stops. Time stands still. He doesn't speak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: O mother mother... What have you done? He falls to his knees, clutching her hand.

direction.raw_text: If not most mortal to him. She looks down at him. His meaning, his foreshadowing, is clear: she has saved Rome, but he knows he is doomed. Rome will live. He will die. This is the price for her victory today.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . She is willing to pay that price. So is he. A moment between them. He accepts his destiny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But let it come. He stands, regains his composure. He slowly walks to Aufidius. He leans close, speaking intimately:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aufidius, though I cannot make true wars, I'll frame convenient peace. Now, good Aufidius, Were you in my stead, would you have

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I dare be sworn you were. And, sir, it is no little thing to make Mine eyes to sweat compassion. But, good sir, What peace you'll make, advise me. We study Aufidius' face. He gives away nothing. Coriolanus turns back to Volumnia. Looks at her. She is victorious. The crimson sky looms over her ominously. And we go to...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A solemn peace treaty signing ceremony. Coriolanus represents the Volscians. Cominius represents the Romans. They sit side-by-side at desks signing the treaty. Volumnia and Virgilia, gorgeously dressed, are present. So too Brutus and Sicinius. The press films everything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It has the stiff formality of a White House ceremony. Cominius concludes signing:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A merrier day did never yet greet Rome, No, not the expulsion of the Tarquins. We have all Great cause to give great thanks. He looks to Volumnia.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Behold our patroness, the life of Rome. She is erect and exalted. "The Life of Rome" personified. She ignores her son. Coriolanus will not look at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A rundown Truck Stop in an industrial wasteland. Garish, buzzing neon. Filthy 18-wheelers refueling. Music droning from a radio. Aufidius, his Lieutenant and seven of his men are waiting outside the dusty diner. The men with Aufidius are thugs and killers, the most brutal Volsces he could find. We note a couple of Coriolanus' Acolytes among them. They have turned with great venom on their hero. They are like a mafia hit squad, waiting for Coriolanus to return with the peace treaty. Aufidius is deep in thought. His Lieutenant breaks the silence:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How is it with our general?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As with a man by his own charity slain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Our soldiers will remain uncertain whilst 'Twixt you there's difference; but the (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: fall of either Makes the survivor heir of all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know it, And my pretext to strike at him admits A good construction. A beat. He continues more to himself than them, almost convincing himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I raised him, and I pawned Mine honor for his truth; who being so heightened, He watered his new plants with dews of flattery, Seducing so my friends. (BITTERLY) At the last I seemed his follower, not partner, and He waged me with his countenance as if I had been mercenary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So he did, my lord. The army marveled at it; and in the last, When he had carried Rome and that we

direction.raw_text: Say no more. In the distance they can see a Roman military truck approaching. Clouds of dust billow up. They exchange a look. This is what they have been waiting for. They stand, stretch and prepare. The truck stops across the highway from them and Coriolanus gets out. He holds a copy of the peace treaty in a leather portfolio. He is unarmed. He stops. He sees Aufidius and the thugs. Waiting for him. Like a death squad. Coriolanus looks at them. He knows exactly what's going to happen. He is ready. He nods and the truck drives off. Coriolanus slowly crosses the highway to the truck stop, like a gunslinger walking down Main Street. There is something new to Coriolanus here. A sort of acceptance. He knows his time is past. Aufidius and the thugs go to meet him. The thugs spread out a bit, strategically, getting ready to strike. Coriolanus' experienced eyes miss none of this. They meet in the parking lot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am returned your soldier, No more infected with my country's love Than when I parted hence, but still
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Under your great command. He hands the treaty portfolio to Aufidius:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have made peace With no less honor to the Volscians Than shame to the Romans.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Measureless liar, thou has made my heart Too great for what contains it. "Boy"? 0 slave. Coriolanus' eyes miss nothing a Volscian thug shifting a bead of sweat on another one secretly reaching into his coat for a weapon. Some of the Volscian thugs are clearly nervous. Coriolanus is ready. He prepares himself mentally to die. He is acutely controlled:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cut me to pieces, Volsces. Men and lads, stain all your edges on me. It is a dare. A challenge.

direction.raw_text: Let him die for it. At this command, his men move-- Aufidius steps back as-- The Volscian thugs attack-- With knives, machetes and tire irons-- Coriolanus fights bravely -- disarming two, grabbing their weapons, killing them, fighting back-- Slashing and cutting his way through the killers- Closer and closer to Aufidius, who just watches-- Blood spattering and spraying- But the thugs overpower Coriolanus, there are just too many--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . They stab him -- slicing with knives -- battering with chains and clubs -- finally emptying pistols him into him-- It is graceless and brutal carnage. Slaughter. But still he comes on. Body riddled with bullets and cut to bits. He refuses to fall. Like something immortal. An obscene demon of blood. Finally the thugs move away. Coriolanus still stands. Teetering. His face is a swollen mask of blood and gore. Blood flows from his body, pooling around his feet, spreading across the parking lot. Aufidius steps forward. What is left of Coriolanus glares at him through blood. Aufidius slowly pulls his knife. The same knife he was sharpening so carefully at the opening of the story. It has finally found its purpose. Coriolanus looks at him. Then slowly Coriolanus tries to raise one bleeding arm this requires superhuman effort his slashed fingers clutch his shirt he rips it open exposing his breast. Ready. He locks eyes with Aufidius. Aufidius steps to him. Takes his neck. Pulls him onto the knife. Driving it into him. Cradling his head like a lover. They stand like this. Then Coriolanus falls. A pause.
direction.name: direction
